sources.title: Ski Troop Attack
sources.description: In a snowy German forest an American patrol has to cross behind enemy lines by skis in order to blow up an important railroad bridge. The task is made harder by conflicts between the platoon's veteran sergeant (Frank Wolff) and its inexperienced lieutenant (Michael Forest) and by constant attacks by pursuing German troops.

sources.description:
Ski Troop Attack (1960) is an American war film directed by Roger Corman, one of the most prolific independent filmmakers of the 20th century. Produced on a tight budget and filmed in the snowy mountains of South Dakota, this World War II adventure tells the story of a small squad of U.S. ski commandos tasked with disrupting German operations behind enemy lines. Shot back-to-back with The Beast from Haunted Cave (1959) to maximize efficiency, Ski Troop Attack is a prime example of Cormanâ€™s ingenuity in low-budget filmmaking.

This restored and colorized edition brings new life to a wartime action film that combines guerrilla tactics, interpersonal conflict, and suspenseful survival against both enemy soldiers and harsh winter conditions. With its snowbound setting and emphasis on resourcefulness, the film stands out from typical battlefield war dramas of its era.

Plot Summary:
During World War II, a small American ski patrol led by the stern but pragmatic Lieutenant (Michael Forest) is assigned a dangerous mission in enemy territory. Their objective is to sabotage a key bridge and disrupt German troop movements. The squad includes the hotheaded Sergeant (Frank Wolff), whose clashes with the Lieutenant create internal tensions, alongside soldiers played by Richard Sinatra and Wally Campo.

As the patrol treks through snow-covered wilderness, they encounter German forces and engage in skirmishes that test their resolve. The harsh winter setting becomes as much an enemy as the Axis soldiers, with avalanches, freezing conditions, and isolation intensifying the danger. Despite the squadâ€™s limited supplies and internal disagreements, their determination drives them to complete their mission.

The climax centers on the sabotage of the enemy-held bridge â€” a sequence that showcases both the ingenuity of Cormanâ€™s direction and the resilience of the soldiers. The men ultimately succeed, though not without losses, underlining the sacrifices of small, unsung units in the broader theater of war.

Film Significance:
Ski Troop Attack is notable for being made with the same cast and crew â€” and even on the same South Dakota locations â€” as Cormanâ€™s horror-crime hybrid The Beast from Haunted Cave. By reusing resources, Corman demonstrated his trademark ability to stretch small budgets into multiple productions. While modest in scale, the film reflects the independent spirit of 1960s genre cinema and foreshadows the later popularity of small-unit war stories in both film and television.

The movie also highlights the work of Michael Forest and Frank Wolff, both of whom would go on to long careers in film and television. For Corman fans, it serves as a fascinating entry in his extensive filmography, representing his early experiments outside the horror and science fiction genres.
